message: I found this code to work :
defaultStyle1Json ends up with two attributes : key1 and key2

defaultStyle1Json=defaultStyle1Json.put({"key1":value1});
defaultStyle1Json=defaultStyle1Json.put({"key2":value2});
If it breaks, you get to keep both pieces :)
Yeah, Horsty told me that I got lucky when I did this. While it may work, it may not work in the future. Buy insurance, don't do it :)
I'll do that from now on.
!! loooooool
okay! that's what you suggested actually !
let me have a look at your module before answering this question
We should make a regression test to document this behavior.
smart move now that we have a regression module
You just earned the #deep_thinker award.
and if your regression module could raise the event "regression detected on put"
then some batch would parse all the rulesets
I want to count the number of test cases and failures (and errors). I guess I'd have to raise an event to make that happen (if only actions could have private postlude{} sections).
I'll share the code, is the .fr address ok?
and mail the authors so they fix their code
or wait! maybe you can create a kynetx app  where people can set preferences like this : I want to receive "regressions alerts" for function1, function2, operator 1 etc...
which can be found here by the way : http://docs.kynetx.com/docs/Regression
what I understood is that thoses "functions" are evaluated on the client
( since we are in a dual execution environment I believe functions should have dual results, one for each environment)
okay, I have no experience with http://docs.kynetx.com/docs/Defaction for now
but you could raise a web event in the client which would fire a counter
so you can't use them in postlude
what about a postlude for defaction ?
Is it  theoretically conceivable to consider KNS as en endpoint so some actions could give a response to KNS instead of a roundtrip to the client ?

"defaction expands the function syntax. Composable actions are defined on the KRL engine, but evaluated on the client (just like traditional actions), so it is important to be mindful of which KRL statements your client supports."
actions run in a defaction() are just like actions normally are.
@loic I don't understand what you mean about "functions" being evaluated in the client. Functions are run engine side, unless you emit javascript.
What do you want a postlude for? I have my own ideas, but don't want to seed them in your mind before you tell me what you were thinking.
some will generate js to run in the browser, some produce directive documents (send_directive), and some do stuff immediately, like http:post()
if we add poslude with have modular reusable ruleset , wouldn't that be
updated the docs, btw. Is that less confusing?
AWESOME
that isn't necessarily true. I'll have to update the docs.
well, that's a deep question.
raise events
http://docs.kynetx.com/docs/Defaction
the answer is that defactions are not rules.
but what that precisely means is still being talked about.

supporting oAuth2 for google in modules is forcing us to find a way to handle the response of an http action before passing the results back to the user. We havn't fully decided which direction we will take on this.
that's what I mean by postlude
what I mean is a place to change persistent vars
( by the way, while you are editing the wiki it would be terrific if you could also update http://docs.kynetx.com/docs/Put and create http://docs.kynetx.com/docs/Delete )
defaction already have some kind of pre block
it does have a pre block.
Horsty is updating the put and delete in the docs.
we have talked about a few things. One of them is exporting rules from modules.
well, yeah. there are plenty of ways we can do it: it's finding the 'right' way that takes some pondering.
KNS as endpoint is one of the thoughts.
when u say raising events? you mean from the client right ?
Updating 'module' persistents from actions would be helpful. I'd like a function in the Regression module to return (#failures, #cases), seems like the only way to do that now is by raising events.
... raising events to update the counters, then a function to return the counts at the end of a test.
Wow, maybe my test cases should just raise events and let the module handle reporting.
No, in this case explicit events from within the defaction(). raise explicit event test_complete with pass = true;
@TelegramSam maybe Sam can clarify that
sorry I don't understand. Is it possible to raise an event inside a defaction , or is it something you wish could be done?
raise explicit event test_complete with pass = false;
Not as clean as the explicit event syntax.
raise explicit event test_error with reason = "Expected a number got a string."
Oh wait, raise explicit event it a postlude thing. It would have to be the KRL raise_event("name") with parameters = {}; action. That you can do inside a defaction.
Another thing I didn't know about : KRL raise_event . From the docs I understsand that KRL raise_event gets translated to javascript : http://docs.kynetx.com/docs/Raise_Event_Action_and_Runtime_API
raising an event in the postlude will add the event to the current schedule, and it will be evaluated in the current request.
that is true of actions generally, so no new info there for defaction.
... It would make sense to provide client-side test infrastructure. Certainly these would raise events to report the results.
so there is a roundtrip
raise_event is a directive for the client: the client will raise the event. So yes, a round trip does occur, and it will be evaluated independantly, not in the same request.

@TelegramSam you asked if http://docs.kynetx.com/docs/Defaction sounded less confusing. I would rather like to know more about what really happens as you explained here : "some will generate js to run in the browser, some produce directive documents (send_directive), and some do stuff immediately, like http:post()"
@TelegramSam  ok and ok
what we need is better explanation of actions in the docs for actions, and a link from defaction docs to there.

We are not just being lazy on our docs there: Getting the explanation right is an important thing, and we've been expanding both our thinking and the platform's abilities recently, and getting the wording and explanations right takes some time.
more time then I'd like, but it is what it is.
Sure. Writing a good doc is art. I suspect some lazyness for the json stuff though ;)
@rsbohn to summarize:  KRL raise_event() inside your regression module would generate a round trip so I'd vote for some postlude inside defaction so you can raise explicit events and mutate vars
the json was not laziness so much as we thought it was in there already. It is very uncharacteristic of Horsty to not provide excellent, timely documentation.
